questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been clinically proven to reduce mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF). It works by decreasing the heart rate, reducing myocardial oxygen demand, and limiting the harmful effects of sympathetic nervous system activation in heart failure. Along with metoprolol and carvedilol, bisoprolol is one of the few beta-blockers approved for use in CHF due to its demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes.

 

Remember - Drugs that decrease mortality are primarily those that inhibit the renin-angiotensin pathway, including beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers), and angiotensin receptor blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not typically used in the management of CHF due to its lack of cardioselectivity. It has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with CHF.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties. While it is useful in the management of hypertensive emergencies, it is not used for chronic management of CHF and has not been shown to decrease mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Pindolol: Pindolol is another non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). It is not suitable for CHF management and does not have evidence supporting a mortality benefit in heart failure patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A patient with hemolytic anemia presents with index finger pain and chest pain. The patient has Hb of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickling crisis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with hemolytic anemia, evidenced by a low hemoglobin level of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, indicating hemolysis. The specific symptoms of index finger pain and chest pain are highly suggestive of a sickling crisis.

 

In sickle cell disease, patients may experience episodes of severe pain, known as sickle cell crises or vaso-occlusive crises, due to the blockage of blood flow by sickled red blood cells. The index finger pain (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome) are classic manifestations of such crises. Acute chest syndrome is a severe complication of sickle cell disease that presents with chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells in small blood vessels but does not typically present with the specific symptoms of dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: While thalassemia also causes hemolytic anemia, it does not usually present with dactylitis or acute chest syndrome.

 

Option D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the immune system attacking red blood cells but lacks the specific signs of sickle cell crisis, such as dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hemolytic anemia presenting with severe pain in the fingers (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome), sickle cell crisis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia after consuming an unknown substance. There was presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following substances was most likely consumed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by the presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) and hypocalcemia, which are key features mentioned in the case.

 

Ethylene glycol is metabolized in the body to glycolic acid and subsequently to oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals, which can precipitate in various tissues, leading to hypocalcemia. The metabolic acidosis arises due to the accumulation of glycolic acid and oxalic acid. Additionally, ethylene glycol poisoning presents with symptoms similar to alcohol intoxication, including tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension, all of which are described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron poisoning typically causes metabolic acidosis but does not lead to hypocalcemia or the specific combination of symptoms described here. Instead, iron toxicity more commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning can also cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis, but it is more associated with visual disturbances and CNS depression rather than hypocalcemia and the specific symptom profile of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity can cause a variety of symptoms including arrhythmias, but it does not typically cause metabolic acidosis or hypocalcemia. Its toxicity is primarily related to cardiac symptoms rather than the systemic effects described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning should be suspected in patients presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and symptoms resembling alcohol intoxication. The formation of oxalate crystals and the subsequent hypocalcemia are key features that differentiate it from other toxic ingestions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Pancoast tumor? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exophthalmos

 

Pancoast tumor is a tumor of the lung apex that involves compression of the sympathetic chain (particularly the stellate ganglion), causing a constellation of symptoms known as Horner's syndrome. 

 

This syndrome includes;

 

  • Miosis (Pupillary Constriction)
  • Anhidrosis (Decreased Sweating)
  • Ptosis (Drooping of The Upper Eyelid)
  • Enophthalmos (Sunken Eye)

 

Exophthalmos, which is the protrusion of the eyeball, is not a feature of Pancoast tumor or Horner's syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective: 


Pancoast tumor causes Horner's syndrome, which includes miosis, anhidrosis, ptosis, and enophthalmos (MAPE). Exophthalmos is not a feature of Pancoast tumor

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical estrogen

 

Explanation

 

Topical estrogen:

 

  • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects.
  • The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. They do not address the underlying cause, which is the lack of estrogen.

 

Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may provide temporary relief from itching but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis, which is estrogen deficiency.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as topical estrogen is the recommended treatment for atrophic vaginitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, particularly in postmenopausal women, is the application of topical estrogen to provide symptomatic relief and address the underlying estrogen deficiency.

 

Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varicella

 

Live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy because pregnancy is an immunocompromised state. Among the given options, Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and therefore contraindicated during pregnancy. This is due to the theoretical risk of transmission of the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause harm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influenza: Incorrect because it is an inactivated vaccine and is actually recommended during pregnancy to protect both mother and baby.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect because it is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. TDaP: Incorrect because it is a toxoid/inactivated vaccine and is recommended during pregnancy to provide passive immunity to the newborn.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Live attenuated vaccines (like Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever) are contraindicated during pregnancy, while killed/inactivated vaccines and toxoids are safe and often recommended during pregnancy.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS, AEFI

 

Contraindications

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis is true except? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Ataxia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic neurological condition often associated with long-term alcohol abuse leading to vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency. The condition is characterized by severe memory issues, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation (fabrication of memories to fill in gaps in recollection). Patients may also experience retrograde amnesia (loss of pre-existing memories).

 

  • Amnesia: This is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff psychosis. Patients have significant difficulty forming new memories and may lose some of their older memories.
  • Confabulation: Another key feature, where patients unknowingly create false memories to fill in the gaps of their amnesia. These fabricated memories are often a mix of true events and imagination but are presented by the patient as genuine recollections.

 

Other options:

 

  • Ophthalmoplegia: This condition, characterized by paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles, is not a feature of Korsakoff psychosis but rather of Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase that can precede Korsakoff syndrome if left untreated.
  • Ataxia: Like ophthalmoplegia, ataxia (lack of voluntary coordination of muscle movements) is a symptom of Wernicke's encephalopathy rather than Korsakoff psychosis. Ataxia affects the patient's gait and movement, but it is not present in the chronic Korsakoff stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is primarily characterized by amnesia and confabulation, not by ophthalmoplegia or ataxia, which are associated with the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy phase of thiamine deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PCR

 

The standard technique for the detection of monkeypox is Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). PCR is a molecular technique used to amplify and detect the DNA of the orthopoxvirus, which includes the monkeypox virus. This method is highly sensitive and specific, making it the preferred choice for diagnosing monkeypox. PCR can detect the presence of orthopoxvirus DNA in various clinical specimens, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While an IgM ELISA test can detect antibodies against monkeypox and can become positive about 5 to 8 days after infection, it is not the primary method for initial detection of the virus itself.

 

Option C. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not typically used for the detection of viral DNA in the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Option D. Hemagglutination: This assay is used to detect the ability of viruses to agglutinate red blood cells. It is not commonly used for the diagnosis of monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

 

The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate or physis, is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones in children and adolescents. It consists primarily of cartilage, made up of type II collagen, which progressively ossifies to contribute to the bone's lengthening. This growth plate remains active until it closes after puberty, marking the end of the bone's longitudinal growth. Any fracture affecting this area, such as a Salter-Harris fracture, can disrupt this growth process, potentially leading to growth disturbances or deformities.

 

The other regions of the bone (diaphysis, epiphysis, and metaphysis) are involved in different processes, but they do not directly influence the longitudinal growth as the epiphyseal plate does.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphysis: This is the shaft of the long bone, primarily involved in providing structural support and is not directly responsible for longitudinal growth. Fractures in the diaphysis do not affect the bone's length.

 

Option B. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone, which forms the joint surface. It plays a role in articulating with adjacent bones and, while important for bone structure, it does not contribute directly to longitudinal growth.

 

Option D. Metaphysis: This is the wide portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and the diaphysis. It is highly vascular and is a common site for bone tumors and infections but is not responsible for the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histone

 

Histones are proteins responsible for DNA packaging. The DNA wraps around histones, forming a structure called a nucleosome. Histones are positively charged proteins that interact with the negatively charged DNA, allowing for efficient packaging and compaction of DNA strands. This packaging is essential for the organization of DNA within the cell nucleus and its regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein: Glycoproteins are not directly involved in DNA packaging. They are molecules composed of a protein and a carbohydrate moiety. While glycoproteins have various functions in the cell, they do not play a role in the compaction and organization of DNA.

 

Option C. Nucleic acid: DNA itself is a type of nucleic acid. DNA molecules are composed of nucleotides and serve as the genetic material of cells. DNA molecules do not package themselves; instead, they interact with histones and other proteins to undergo packaging and compaction.

 

Option D. Helicases: Helicases are enzymes responsible for unwinding and separating the DNA strands during processes such as DNA replication and transcription. They do not participate in DNA packaging; instead, their role is to facilitate the access of various cellular machinery to the DNA template.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins

 

Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO42- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 351

choices.text: To evaluate the risk of surgery
To evaluate the pros and cons of surgery
To evaluate the fitness of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is the use of Mallampati classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endotracheal intubation

 

The Mallampati classification is a widely used clinical tool for predicting the ease of endotracheal intubation. This classification assesses the visibility of the structures at the back of the oropharynx. The patient is asked to open their mouth and protrude their tongue, and the visibility of the tonsillar pillars, uvula, and soft palate is observed.

 

  • Mallampati classes:
    • Class I: Full visibility of the tonsils, uvula, and soft palate.
    • Class II: Visibility of the uvula and soft palate.
    • Class III: Only the base of the uvula is visible.
    • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

 

The higher the Mallampati score, the more difficult it may be to intubate the patient. Therefore, this classification is specifically used for evaluating the potential difficulty of airway management, particularly during endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. To evaluate the risk of surgery: The evaluation of surgical risk is typically done using the ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification, not the Mallampati classification.

 

Option C. To evaluate the pros and cons of surgery: This is a broad evaluation that involves multiple factors, including patient history and overall health, not just the airway assessment. The Mallampati classification is not relevant here.

 

Option D. To evaluate the fitness of the patient: General fitness or readiness for surgery involves various physiological and clinical assessments, but Mallampati classification is solely concerned with airway assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is used to assess the difficulty of airway assessment, particularly for endotracheal intubation.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Activation of PKA
  3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that act via an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) follow a specific sequence of events in the signal transduction pathway. The steps involved are as follows:

 

1. Activation of Adenylate Cyclase: Upon ligand binding to the G-stimulatory GPCR, the receptor activates adenylate cyclase.

 

3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP: The activated adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP).

 

2. Activation of Protein Kinase A (PKA): The increased levels of cAMP activate protein kinase A (PKA).

 

4. Phosphorylation of Target Proteins: PKA then phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to the desired cellular response.

 

This sequence of events accurately describes the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs is: Activation of adenylate cyclase, conversion of ATP to cAMP, activation of PKA, and phosphorylation of target proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following component is absent in the smooth muscle? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not contain troponin. In smooth muscle cells, actin and myosin are present and are essential for muscle contraction. Tropomyosin is also present in smooth muscle, though its role differs from that in skeletal muscle. While in skeletal muscle, tropomyosin blocks the myosin binding sites on actin filaments, its function in smooth muscle is still not completely understood but is thought to aid in muscle contraction. Troponin, however, is absent in smooth muscle.

 

In skeletal muscle, troponin binds to calcium ions during muscle contraction, facilitating the interaction between actin and myosin.

 

Smooth muscle uses calmodulin to bind calcium instead of troponin, enabling muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actin: Actin is present in smooth muscle and plays a crucial role in the contraction process by interacting with myosin.

 

Option B. Myosin: Myosin is also present in smooth muscle and is essential for contraction as it interacts with actin.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is present in smooth muscle. Although its exact role differs from that in skeletal muscle, it is involved in the contraction mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Troponin is absent in smooth muscle; instead, calcium binds to calmodulin to facilitate muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Her ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm, consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Her blood pressure is stable. What is the first-line drug of choice for treating this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine

 

Explanation:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment after attempting vagal maneuvers.

 

Adenosine is preferred because:

 

  • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds)
  • Effectively terminates most forms of SVT by blocking AV nodal conduction
  • Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Not first-line therapy for acute SVT. More commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias or refractory SVT

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Effective for rate control in AF, but not the first choice for acute SVT termination

 

Option D. Verapamil: Used for SVT treatment, but not first-line due to risk of hypotension and bradycardia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), administered as a rapid IV push following vagal maneuvers.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with history of consuming polished rice presents with confusion and tingling sensation. He has no edema on examination. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beriberi

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests beriberi, specifically dry beriberi. The key factors leading to this diagnosis are:

 

  1. Chronic alcoholism, which can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency
  2. Diet consisting of polished rice, which is low in thiamine
  3. Neurological symptoms: confusion and tingling sensation (peripheral neuropathy)
  4. Absence of edema, which distinguishes it from wet beriberi

 

Dry beriberi primarily affects the nervous system, causing peripheral neuropathy and confusion, as seen in this case. The lack of edema is a crucial point in differentiating it from wet beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular system and typically presents with edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pellagra: Incorrect. Pellagra is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency and typically presents with the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death if untreated. While confusion could be a symptom, the characteristic skin changes and gastrointestinal symptoms are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Phrynoderma: Incorrect. Phrynoderma is a skin condition associated with vitamin A deficiency. It presents with rough, dry skin with follicular hyperkeratosis, which is not mentioned in this patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Psoriasis: Incorrect. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition affecting the skin, causing red, scaly patches. It is not related to nutritional deficiencies and doesn't explain the neurological symptoms described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcoholism combined with a diet high in polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in dry beriberi characterized by neurological symptoms without edema.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the forearm. Microscopic examination reveals the following features. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malignant tumor with frequent metastasis

 

The image shows the characteristic microscopic appearance of a schwannoma, which shows hypercellular areas (Antoni A) and hypocellular areas (Antoni B) with Verocay bodies (nuclear palisading). 

 

Schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from Schwann cells. 

 

Schwannomas are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and show nuclear palisading. 

 

The statement that it is a "malignant tumor with frequent metastasis" is incorrect because schwannomas are benign tumors with excellent prognosis and do not typically metastasize. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SCHWANNOMA

 

  • Peripheral Nerve sheath tumor
  • Benign
  • Arises from Schwann cells of Peripheral nerves or Cranial nerves (8th CN > 5th CN)

 

Risk factor:

 

  • NF2 gene mutation causes reduced merlin expression and increased cell multiplication
  • B/L schwannoma due to NF-2 gene mutation
  • Schwannoma arising from 8th CN was earlier called acoustic neuroma
  • Now called as vestibular schwannoma
  • C/F: SNHL, tinnitus, decreased corneal reflex
  • Diagnosed with MRI

 

Histology shows

 

  1. Hypercellular Antony 'A' area and hypocellular Antony 'B' area
    • Antony 'A' area: tumor cells arranged in fence-like pattern → nuclear-free zones called verocay bodies
  2. Verocay body: Nuclear free area
  3. Presence of true palisading
  4. IHC shows S100+
